text:
```julia> using GalaxyBrain, BenchmarkTools

julia> bench = bf""">++[<+++++++++++++>-]<[[>+>+<<-]>[<+>-]++++++++
       [>++++++++<-]>.[-]<<>++++++++++[>++++++++++[>++
       ++++++++[>++++++++++[>++++++++++[>++++++++++[>+
       +++++++++[-]<-]<-]<-]<-]<-]<-]<-]++++++++++."""
#1 (generic function with 1 method)

julia> @btime $(bench)()
(a bunch of printing later)
  101.619 ms (86 allocations: 31.56 KiB)```
C++ time, the fastest for bench.b, is listed as `0.892±0.022` seconds

elements.text: C++ time, the fastest for bench.b, is listed as
seconds

text: That's hilarious :joy: Big fan of GalaxyBrain. To be fair, I think a Brainfuck interpreter is a decent enough microbenchmark of a programming language, right? The point of microbenchmarks isn't the work done, it's just to illustrate a workload of some kind.

elements.text: That's hilarious

Big fan of GalaxyBrain. To be fair, I think a Brainfuck interpreter is a decent enough microbenchmark of a programming language, right? The point of microbenchmarks isn't the work done, it's just to illustrate a workload of some kind.

text:
Y'ALL. look what happens when I set this up:
```julia> @btime $(mandel)(; output=devnull, memory_size=500)
  1.010 s (3 allocations: 784 bytes)

julia> @btime $(bench)(; output=devnull, memory_size=100)
  96.103 ms (3 allocations: 352 bytes)```

elements.text: Y'ALL. look what happens when I set this up:

julia> @btime $(mandel)(; output=devnull, memory_size=500)
  1.010 s (3 allocations: 784 bytes)

julia> @btime $(bench)(; output=devnull, memory_size=100)
  96.103 ms (3 allocations: 352 bytes)
